text: for many of us the land beneath our feet
provides not just a place to call home
but also the means to earn a living from
forests to fish owns more than a third
of the world's labor force works in
agriculture on average women make up 43
percent of the workforce within
developing countries
yet where there is data they comprise
less than a fifth of land holders across
developing regions access to both secure
tenure and ownership of land remains
much harder for women than men and some
of the biggest barriers surround
marriage and inheritance particularly
where traditional cultural practice or
even legal provision favors men over
women in nearly all countries where data
exists small-scale farms operated by
female-headed households are smaller on
average than those of their male peers
and in some cases up to half the size
furthermore by some estimates yields
achieved by female farmers can be as
much as 20 to 30 percent lower than male
farmers why what most studies suggests
is that this imbalance exists not
because women are listed the men but
because in many cases they lack equal
access to resources such as seeds
fertilizers and equipment
by addressing this disparity the
additional yields could be enough to
reduce the number of malnourished people
but as much as 70% that's 150 million or
equivalent to the population of Russia
establishing equal rights to land and
resources for both men and women may not
only be a moral issue or one of
empowerment but an economic one too
